original_text:
**INSTITUTION
TRAUMA
TRANSFER SUMMARY
PATIENT NAME :
**NAME[AAA , BBB M]
ACCOUNT # :
**ID-NUM
**ROOM
ATTENDING PHYSICIAN :
**NAME[YYY M ZZZ]
ADMISSION DATE :
**DATE[Jul 03 2007]
TRANSFER DATE :
**DATE[Jul 08 07]
TRANSFERRED TO :
TRANSFERRED TO CARE OF :
DISPOSITION :
The patient is being discharged to a rehabilitation facility .
TRANSFER DIAGNOSIS ( ES ) :
1. TYPE 3 ODONTOID FRACTURE .
2. LEFT TIBIAL PLATEAU FRACTURE .
3. SMALL SUBARACHNOID HEMORRHAGE , RESOLVED .
CONSULTANTS :
Orthopedic Surgery and Neurosurgery .
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS :
Ms. **NAME[AAA] is a **AGE[in 70s]- year - old female who presented to **INSTITUTION on **DATE[Jul 03 2007] after being involved in a motor vehicle accident .
The patient was an unrestrained driver who did experience loss of consciousness at the scene .
Upon arrival in the Emergency Department , the patient got intubated .
The patient had large scalp lacerations and a right ecchymotic peri - orbital eye upon initial evaluation .
CT of the head in the ED revealed a small right subarachnoid hemorrhage and a type 3 odontoid fracture .
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY :
1. Hypertension .
2. Diabetes .
3. Coronary artery disease .
4. GERD .
5. Hyperlipidemia .
6. Glaucoma .
7. Depression .
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION :
On admission , the patient had a large scalp laceration and a peri - orbital ecchymotic right eye .
LABORATORY , RADIOGRAPHIC , AND OTHER DIAGNOSTIC STUDY FINDINGS :
On admission , hemoglobin 8.5 and hematocrit 27 .
Glucose 314 , sodium 133 , and potassium 5.8 .
HOSPITAL COURSE :
The patient was admitted to the 4G Unit in stable condition for further evaluation and treatment .
The patient did remain stable throughout her stay in the Emergency Department and remained in her C collar at all times .
The patient was placed in a brace of the left lower extremity due to a left tibial plateau fracture .
The patient 's hemoglobin became low during her stay , and she required 3 units of blood total .
Hemoccult of her stool was negative .
The patient 's hemoglobin subsequently began to rise slightly and was 8.4 upon discharge .
A repeat H&amp ; H will be performed on Wednesday at the rehabilitation center .
The patient performed well during her physical therapy and was deemed well enough to be transferred to an outside rehabilitation center at this time .
TRANSFER INSTRUCTIONS :
Medications -
1. Lipitor 40 mg p.o. at bedtime .
2. Coreg 6.25 mg p.o. twice daily .
3. Docusate sodium 100 mg p.o. twice daily .
4. Keppra 500 mg p.o. twice daily .
5. Lisinopril 40 mg p.o. daily .
6. Metformin 500 mg p.o. twice daily .
7. Pantoprazole 40 mg p.o. daily .
8. Timolol ophthalmic one drop each eye daily .
9. Effexor XR 75 mg p.o. daily .
10. Bimatoprost ophthalmic one drop each eye daily .
11. Effexor XR 75 mg p.o. daily .
12. Vicodin 5 mg p.o. one to two tablets q. 4 to 6 hours p.r.n. pain .
13. Bisacodyl 10 mg per rectum q. a.m. p.r.n. constipation .
Follow - up / plan - The patient will be instructed to follow with the **INSTITUTION , Neurosurgery , and Orthopedics upon discharge from the rehabilitation center .
_______________________________
**NAME[YYY M ZZZ] , M.D.
Dictator :
**NAME[WWW XXX] , D.O.
SS/ecr
